title: Week 8: Shiny apps
description: This week you will learn how to create interactive web pages to present your results to the world. These interactive web pages can be created using the shiny package, and only require you to know R—they write the javascript in the background!

title: Week 1: Welcome to Stat 220!
description: This week we'll discuss an overview of the course, review some fundamental concepts about R, and get up and running with some new reproducibility tools.
contents:
Contents
Wednesday, 15 Sept
Friday, 17 Sept

Wednesday, 15 Sept
Announcements
Welcome!
Topics/activities
Intro slides html | pdf
What is data science?
What is this course about?
Before next time
Please sign up for two collaborative note slots
Make sure all software is installed and working
Connect Git and GitHub following the directions in the GitHub Classroom Guide for Stat 220(you only need to worry about the “Getting setup with Git and GitHub” for now.)
Read Sections 27.1-27.5 in R4DS. This reviews and expands on using R Markdown for literate programming.
Watch “Git and GitHub for Poets (part 1)”. This introduces basic ideas, but we’ll use RStudio to interface with Git and GitHub.

Optional (if you need more review):
If you don’t remember how to use R Markdown from your last statistics class, read R and RStudio Basics and R Markdown from Getting Used to R, RStudio, and R Markdown
If it’s been a LONG time since you used R and need a crash course on the very basics, watch this programming basics primer from RStudio.
Friday, 17 Sept
Announcements
Homework 1 is due by 8:30 a.m. on Wednesday, September 22.
Topics/activities
Slides: html | pdf
Example .Rmd report (for your turns)
Collaborative notes
Reproducible workflows
Getting up and running with R Markdown
Connecting to GitHub
Before next time
Make sure that you have access to homework 1 on GitHub. You can start working on it now, but it won’t be due until Wednesday (notice that change in due date). I’ll also review how to clone the project and use GitHub on Monday.
Watch this video on the R fundamentals (here are the slides) or read Sections 2.2-2.13 in Irizazary, whichever works best for your learning style. These materials review the fundamentals of working with vectors in R. Feel free to skip the exercises for now, focus on reviewing the basics.

title: Getting setup for Stat 220
description:
Please work through this guide and install/update the necessary
software **before** the first day of class.
contents:
To get the class up an running quickly at the beginning of the term, please do the following before the first day of class:
Read through this software overview and installation guide. If you will be working on your own computer, then please try to have R, RStudio, Git, and LaTeX installed. I’m happy to help with troubleshooting during student hours.
Sign up for a GitHub account using your Carleton email: https://github.com/. I recommend choosing a username that incorporates your name (e.g. aloy or AdamLoy).
Edit your GitHub profile. Please add your name and a cropped picture of you (to help me learn names faster).
Sign up for Slack following the directions on the guide. Once you have joined the class workspace, go to the “discussion” channel and introduce yourself.
Fill out this pre-class survey. You’ll submit your GitHub username here, so be sure to complete the other steps first!
